content: The "Crane Conservation Act of 2003" may be cited as such. Key findings are outlined in the Act. The "Crane Conservation Act of 2003" highlights the serious decline in crane populations globally, especially in Africa, Asia, and Europe. Five species of Asian cranes are endangered, including the Siberian crane, red-crowned crane, and white-naped crane. The Crane Action Plan identifies seriously threatened crane species including the wattled crane, blue crane, grey-crowned crane, black-crowned crane, white-naped crane, black-necked crane, and hooded crane. The whooping crane and Mississippi sandhill crane are endangered species with limited populations, making them vulnerable to extinction. Conservation efforts have been insufficient to adequately protect these species. Conservation resources are inadequate to address the decline of crane populations due to hunting and habitat loss. Cranes play a vital role in conserving wetland, grassland, and agricultural landscapes. Establishing crane conservation programs would benefit many other endangered species. Threats to cranes also include the collection of eggs and juveniles. To effectively address threats to crane populations, efforts from countries in Africa, Asia, and North America, as well as the private sector, are required. Cranes are important ambassadors for promoting goodwill among countries due to their well-known migration patterns. Threats to cranes include poisoning from insecticides, collisions with power lines, disturbance from warfare and human settlement, and trapping of live birds for sale. Conservation efforts for cranes are crucial across continents due to similar threats they face globally. Successes in one region can be applied to others, and collaboration between countries is essential for effective conservation. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of cranes, support conservation programs in countries where endangered cranes occur, assist private organizations dedicated to crane conservation, and provide financial resources for these efforts. The term "conservation" in this Act refers to methods to ensure the population of crane species in the wild is sufficient to prevent extinction, including habitat protection and management. The Act focuses on conservation efforts for crane species in the wild, including habitat management, research, enforcement, community involvement, reintroduction, conflict resolution, and education. The Act emphasizes conservation efforts for crane species in the wild, including habitat management, research, enforcement, reintroduction, conflict resolution, and community outreach and education. Key terms defined include Convention, Fund, and Secretary. SEC. 5. CRANE CONSERVATION ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will use funds from the Fund to provide financial assistance for crane conservation projects with approved proposals. Applicants seeking assistance for such projects must submit proposals to the Secretary. Applicants for crane conservation projects must submit project proposals meeting specific requirements to the Secretary. Eligible applicants include wildlife management authorities in countries within the range of crane species. Eligible applicants for crane conservation projects must submit project proposals to the Secretary, including a concise statement of the project's purpose and the names of individuals responsible for conducting it. Applicants for crane conservation projects must submit project proposals to the Secretary, including a description of individuals involved, methods, staff management, logistics, funding estimate, and project support evidence. Applicants for crane conservation projects must provide evidence of government support, details on matching funding, and any other necessary information for project eligibility under this Act. The Secretary must review project proposals within 30 days of receiving them and consult with other Federal officials. Within 180 days of receiving a proposal, the Secretary will approve or disapprove after ensuring it meets the criteria outlined in subsection (d). After consulting with appropriate Federal officials, the Secretary must consult with the government of each country where the project will be carried out, approve or disapprove the proposal, and notify the applicant and other officials of the decision. The Secretary may approve a project proposal under this section if it will enhance conservation programs for cranes, address conflicts between humans and cranes, and ensure compliance with relevant laws. The Secretary may approve projects to enhance compliance with laws regulating crane taking, trade, habitat use, and management. Projects also aim to develop scientific information on crane habitat, population trends, and threats, as well as promote cooperative projects on these issues. The curr_chunk focuses on carrying out scientific research on cranes, reintroducing them successfully into the wild, and providing training and support for effective conservation efforts. The curr_chunk focuses on enhancing conservation efforts for cranes and their habitats, prioritizing projects that ensure long-term effectiveness and have matching funds available. Recipients of assistance must report project progress to the Secretary periodically. The Secretary determines periodic reporting requirements for project evaluation, ensuring positive results, assessing problems, and fostering improvements. Reports and related documents must be made available to the public. The Secretary convenes a panel of experts biennially to identify conservation needs for cranes, including specialists on cranes and wetlands. Additionally, there is a Crane Conservation Fund established. Establishment of the Crane Conservation Fund within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund, consisting of transferred amounts, appropriations, and interest earned on investments. The Crane Conservation Fund is established within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer necessary amounts to provide assistance under section 5. Administrative expenses are limited to 3% or $80,000 from the Fund for each fiscal year. The Crane Conservation Fund, part of the Multinational Species Conservation Fund, limits administrative expenses to 3% or $80,000 per fiscal year. Not more than 50% of the Fund can be used for North American crane conservation projects. The Secretary of the Treasury invests remaining Fund amounts in interest-bearing US obligations. The Crane Conservation Fund limits administrative expenses to 3% or $80,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary of the Treasury invests remaining Fund amounts in interest-bearing US obligations, which can be acquired on original issue or by purchase of outstanding obligations at market price. Any obligations acquired by the Fund may be sold at market price, with interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. The Fund receives monthly transfers from the Treasury based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments are made for any excess or insufficient transfers. The Secretary is allowed to accept and utilize donations. The Secretary can accept donations to provide assistance under section 5, and these donations will be transferred to the Secretary of the Treasury for deposit in the Fund. SEC. 7. ADVISORY GROUP. The Secretary may convene an advisory group of individuals involved in crane conservation, ensuring public participation in meetings with timely notice provided. The Secretary may convene an advisory group for crane conservation with timely notice of meetings. Minutes of each meeting shall be kept and made available to the public. Authorization of appropriations for the Fund is set at $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2007, with funds remaining available until expended.
